questions.text: A clinician notes relative bradycardia in a patient with fever and respiratory symptoms. Which of the following infections is most commonly associated with relative bradycardia?

A 28-year-old male presents with a history of fever, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. His temperature has been rising stepwise over the past five days. Physical examination reveals bradycardia and a faint rash on the abdomen. Blood cultures are positive for Salmonella typhi . Based on the diagnosis, what is the most likely fever pattern?
questions.explanation:
Fever Pattern

Description

Associated Conditions

Fever Graph

Sustained Fever

Continuous elevated temperature.

Typhoid fever, tuberculosis, bacterial pneumonia, neoplasms, connective tissue diseases

Intermittent Fever

Fever spikes followed by normal temperature. (Option A ruled out)

Malaria, brucellosis

Remittent Fever

Fever fluctuates above normal without returning to baseline. (Option B ruled out)

Various infectious diseases

Hectic Fever

High temperatures with wide fluctuations.

Severe infections like bacteremia

  

Pel-Ebstein Fever

Weeks of high fevers followed by normal periods. (Option C ruled out)

Hodgkin's disease

  

Double Quotidian Fever

Two fever spikes within 24 hours.

Adult Still's disease, malaria

Tertian Fever

Fever occurs every third day.

Malaria

Quartan Fever

Fever occurs every fourth day.

Malaria

Periodic Fever Syndromes

Regular intervals of fever episodes.

Cyclic neutropenia

  

Infection

Fever Pattern Description

Malaria
  • P. vivax/P. ovale: alternate days;
  • P. malariae: every third day;
  • P. falciparum: no specific pattern

Dengue

Continuous or "saddle-back" fever with breaks on days 4-5

Yellow Fever

Recrudescence after initial resolution with back pain, jaundice

Louse-borne Relapsing Fever

Crisis after 4-10 days, profuse sweating, possible relapses

Typhoid Fever

Stepladder rise over 4-5 days with malaise and headaches

questions.text: Which of the following statements about malarial fever is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Quotidian fever is associated with P. falciparum infection .

options.label: C
options.text: Quartan fever is linked to P. malariae.

options.label: D
options.text: Quotidian fever is associated with P. ovale.

questions.correct_answer: D. Quotidian fever is associated with P. ovale.
questions.explanation:
Type of Fever

Characteristics

Examples

Quotidian Fever

(Option A)
  • Fever occurs once every day, and it will touch the baseline.

P. falciparum, P. knowlesi

Tertian Fever (Option B)
  • Fever is occurring every 48 hours.

P. vivax, P. ovale

Quartan Fever (Option C)
  • Fever will occur after every 72 hours.

P. malariae

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F) that has persisted for three weeks. He reports significant weight loss, night sweats, and fatigue. His medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, he has splenomegaly and mild lymphadenopathy. Which investigation would be the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?

options.label: C
options.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.correct_answer: C. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
questions.explanation:
Category

Common Causes

Other Causes

Infections
  • Tuberculosis (military or disseminated / extra-pulmonary)
  • Endocarditis (culture negative)
  • Deep-seated infections (abscesses, prostatitis, etc.)
  • Typhoidal and non-typhoidal Salmonella
  • Emerging Infections: HIV, Leishmaniasis, Melioidosis
  • Travelers: Malaria, Visceral leishmaniasis, Histoplasmosis

Neoplasms
  • Malignant lymphomas
  • Renal-cell carcinoma, hepatocellular cancer
  • Ovarian cancer, atrial myxoma
  • Castleman disease, brain tumors

Auto-inflammatory and Autoimmune Disorders
  • Giant-cell arteritis, Polymyalgia rheumatica (elderly)
  • Adult-onset Still's disease (younger)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease, certain types of uveitis, Behçet's syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, polymyositis
  • PAN, small vessel vasculitis, FMF

Miscellaneous
  • Granulomatous: Kikuchi disease, Sarcoidosis, Granulomatous hepatitis
  • Vascular: atrial myxoma, pulmonary emboli, hematomas
  • Endocrine: thyrotoxicosis, thyroiditis, Pheochromocytoma
  • Hematologic: HUS, TTP
  • Cirrhosis, Pancreatitis, Factitious fever
  • Drug fever (3-7% of febrile episodes in hospitalized patients; 1/3 due to antibiotics - beta-lactams)
  • DRESS, Hyperthermic drug syndromes (NMS, Serotonin syndrome)

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered an autoinflammatory syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Category

Examples

Systemic Rheumatic and Autoimmune Diseases
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Behçet's disease
  • Mixed connective-tissue disease
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Sjögren's syndrome
  • SLE
  • Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome(VKH Syndrome)

Vasculitis
  • Allergic vasculitis
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Giant cell vasculitis/polymyalgia rheumatica
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Kawasaki disease
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Takayasu arteritis

Granulomatous Diseases
  • Idiopathic granulomatous hepatitis, sarcoidosis

Autoinflammatory Syndromes (Option A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Adult-onset Still's disease
  • CAPS (cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes)
  • Familial Mediterranean fever
  • Hyper-IgD syndrome (HIDS, also known as mevalonate kinase deficiency)
  • PAPA syndrome (pyogenic sterile arthritis, pyoderma gangrenosum, and acne)
  • PFAPA syndrome (periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, adenitis)
  • SAPHO (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteomyelitis)
  • TRAPS (tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a fever of 39°C that has persisted for the past five days. She reports severe muscle pain, nausea, and retroorbital pain. On examination, she has mild dehydration and a positive tourniquet test. Which of the following investigations would be most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Test Type

Description

ELISA
  • IgM dengue virus (MAC-ELISA)
  • Positive by Day 4 of infection
  • Indicates recent infection

NAAT
  • Detects viral RNA
  • Useful for early diagnosis

NS-1 Antigen
  • NS-1 (IgG)
  • Positive on Day 1 of infection
  • Should be performed within 7 days of symptom onset

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with a one-week history of fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, and myalgia. Skin examination reveals multiple purpura and petechiae on the left shoulder, trunk, and legs. Similar cases have been reported linked to increased incidence of mosquito breeding. What is the most common neurological complication associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus (Option A)
    • linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.
  • Encephalitis (Option D ruled out)
  • GBS (Option B ruled out)
  • Stroke (Option C ruled out)

Cardiomyopathy
  • Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever

All of the following:

  • Acute onset of fever
  • 2-7 days duration
  • Hemorrhagic manifestations
    • Positive tourniquet test/Petechiae
    • Ecchymosis
    • Purpura/Bleeding from mucosa, GIT, Injection sites, etc
  • Platelet count ≤ 100,000 cells/cu.mm.
  • Plasma leakage
    • Rising hematocrit
      • Hemoconcentration >20%
    • Pleural effusion, ascites/Hypoproteinemia)

Dengue Shock Syndrome
  • DHF criteria plus Signs of Shock
  • Tachycardia/Cool extremities/Weak pulse/Lethargy/Restlessness
  • Pulse pressure <20 mm Hg with increased Diastolic pressure (e.g. 100/80)
  • Hypotension (Systolic <80 mm Hg for age <5 years/80-90 mm Hg for older child and adults)

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a fever of 39°C for the past three days. She reports muscle aches and mild retro-orbital pain but denies any gastrointestinal symptoms. On examination, she is alert, has a dry mouth, and a rash on her trunk, and her vital signs are stable. She has passed urine twice in the last six hours. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for her management?

options.label: D
options.text: Admit to the hospital for observation

questions.explanation:
Group A (Outpatient)

  • No warning signs:
    • Abdominal pain or tenderness
    • Persistent vomiting
    • Clinical fluid accumulation
    • Mucosal bleed
    • Lethargy or restlessness
    • Liver enlargement > 2 cm
    • Hematocrit count Rise >20% admission value
    • Rapid decrease in platelet count
  • And who are able to:
    • Tolerate adequate volumes of oral fluids
    • To pass urine at least once every 6 hours

Treatment

  • Plenty of fluids- ORS, coconut water (avoid excess plain water)
  • Paracetamol(500-650 mg per dose) for high fever
    • Dosing should not be less than six hours
  • Tepid sponge if the patient still has high fever
  • Don't take: aspirin, ibuprofen, diclofenac or mefenamic acid (Option C ruled out)
  • Report to hospital immediately if
    • Bleeding
    • Vomiting
    • Severe abdomen pain
    • Drowsiness
    • Breathing difficulty
    • Not passing urine > 6 hours

Group B (Inpatient)

  • Warning signs present or
  • Coexisting:
    • Pregnancy, infancy, old age
    • Obesity, diabetes mellitus, renal failure
    • Chronic hemolytic diseases or
  • Social:
    • Living alone or living far from a health facility without reliable means of transport

Note: Group C (ICU)

  • For Hemodynamically unstable Dengue

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the hospital with fever, muscle aches, vomiting, and respiratory distress after consuming contaminated palm sap in a region known for bat activity. Laboratory tests reveal elevated white blood cell counts in his cerebrospinal fluid. Based on the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings, which of the following statements regarding Nipah virus infection is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The virus is primarily transmitted from human to human through respiratory droplets.

options.label: B
options.text: Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment, as there are no approved antiviral therapies specifically for Nipah virus.

options.label: C
options.text: The incubation period for Nipah virus infection is usually less than 4 days.

options.label: D
options.text: Ribavirin is the first-line antiviral treatment with established efficacy in humans.

questions.correct_answer: B. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment, as there are no approved antiviral therapies specifically for Nipah virus.
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Method

Description

Laboratory Tests
  • PCR for viral RNA detection
  • ELISA for IgM and IgG antibodies
  • CSF analysis for elevated WBC or protein levels

Imaging Studies
  • MRI or CT scans to assess neurological involvement (not specific for NiV)

Agent

Notes

Ribavirin

Mixed results; efficacy remains controversial (Option D ruled out)

m102.4

Monoclonal antibody, promising in animal studies, used compassionately in humans

Favipiravir

Under investigation, requires further validation

Remdesivir

Under investigation, requires further validation

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with fever, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash after returning from a trip to Central America. Her clinical presentation is suggestive of Zika virus infection. Which of the following statements about Zika virus (ZIKV) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Transmitted only through infected bodily fluids.

options.label: C
options.text: Complications include microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome.

options.label: D
options.text: Reliable diagnosis via serology in the first week.

questions.correct_answer: C. Complications include microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Incubation period
  • 3–12 days (Option B ruled out)

Symptomatic presentation
  • Fever, arthralgia, conjunctivitis, maculopapular rash

Possible complications
  • Guillain–Barré syndrome
  • Congenital microcephaly

Other congenital issues
  • Cerebral calcification
  • Deafness
  • Vision problems
  • Joint contractures (arthrogryposis)
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Growth retardation

Infection target
  • Neural progenitor cells

Test Type

Findings

Routine blood tests

Possible leucopenia, thrombocytopenia, or elevated transaminases (often normal)

PCR test

Detects ZIKV in blood (first week) or urine (up to 14 days)

Serology

Retrospective diagnosis; cross-reactivity with other flaviviruses (Option D ruled out)

Plaque-reduction neutralisation testing

Detects virus-specific neutralising antibodies to differentiate primary infections.

Prevention Method

Recommendations

Mosquito bite prevention

Primary method to avoid infection

Sexual health precautions

Infected individuals: safe sex for 6 months

Delay pregnancy for 6 months

Asymptomatic travelers

Safe sex and avoid pregnancy for 2 months after returning

Vaccination status

No vaccine currently available

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with progressive bilateral lower limb weakness over the past 10 days. On examination, he has flaccid paralysis and absent deep tendon reflexes in the affected limbs. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals a normal white cell count with elevated protein levels. Nerve conduction studies confirm a demyelinating pattern. Based on the Brighton criteria, which level of diagnostic certainty for Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) does this patient fulfill?
questions.explanation:
Level

Criteria

Level 1
  • No alternative diagnosis for weakness
  • Diminished/absent deep tendon reflexes in weak limbs
  • Monophasic course: onset to nadir within 12 hours to 28 days
  • Bilateral flaccid limb weakness
  • CSF cell count < 50 cells/microlitre
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration
  • Nerve conduction study (NCS) consistent with GBS subtype

Level 2
  • All Level 1 criteria met, with possible variations (e.g., present reflexes in some cases). (Option B ruled out)

Level 3
  • Most Level 1 criteria met but lacking one or more key features. (Option C ruled out)

Level 4
  • Minimal criteria were met; these may include atypical or incomplete presentations. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with fever, dry cough, and progressive shortness of breath. His CD4+ count is 150 cells/mm³. Chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of infection in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary infection acquired from a contaminated water source

options.label: B
options.text: Airborne transmission from an infected individual

options.label: C
options.text: Ingestion of fungal spores from environmental reservoirs

options.label: D
options.text: Reactivation of a previously dormant infection acquired during childhood

questions.correct_answer: B. Airborne transmission from an infected individual

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with HIV presents with low-grade fever, nonproductive cough, and progressive shortness of breath over the past month. His HRCT shows bilateral ground-glass opacities. Which of the following statements correctly differentiates PCP in HIV-infected patients from non-HIV individuals?

options.label: A
options.text: PCP in HIV-infected patients usually present with acute onset and severe oxygenation impairment.

options.label: B
options.text: Non-HIV patients with PCP experience a gradual onset with mild respiratory distress.

options.label: C
options.text: HIV-infected individuals typically have a chronic presentation with milder respiratory distress initially.

options.label: D
options.text: Mortality in HIV-infected PCP cases is higher (30-60%) compared to non-HIV individuals.

questions.correct_answer: C. HIV-infected individuals typically have a chronic presentation with milder respiratory distress initially.
questions.explanation:
Parameter

HIV-Infected Patients

Non-HIV Patients

Onset

Gradual (2 weeks to 2 months) (Option A ruled out)

Sudden (within a week) (Option B ruled out)

Symptom Severity

Milder respiratory distress initially

Rapid progression to respiratory failure (Option B ruled out)

Course

Chronic

Acute

Oxygen Impairment

Less severe (Option A ruled out)

More severe

Group

Mortality Rate

Non-HIV Patients

30%–60% (Option D ruled out)

HIV-Infected Patients

10%–20%

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with a persistent cough, dyspnea, and fever. A chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. Sputum examination is inconclusive, and a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed. Which of the following diagnostic methods is most likely to provide the highest sensitivity for confirming the presence of Pneumocystis jirovecii ?
questions.explanation:
Type

Findings

Chest X-ray

Bilateral infiltrates, ground-glass opacities. (Option B ruled out)

CT Scan

More sensitive; shows ground-glass opacities, cystic lesions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of HIV presents with worsening dyspnea and a dry cough. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral infiltrates, and a diagnosis of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is made. Which of the following is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Treatment

Administration

Indication

Pentamidine

IV: 4 mg/kg/day

For patients intolerant to TMP/SMX (Option A ruled out)

Atovaquone

Oral: 750 mg twice daily

Effective for mild to moderate PCP, fewer side effects (Option C ruled out)

Clindamycin + Primaquine

Combination therapy

For patients failing TMP/SMX or pentamidine (Option D ruled out)

Dapsone

Alone or with TMP

For prophylaxis and treatment in select cases

Caspofungin

Combination with low-dose TMP/SMX

For severe cases
